awd_titl_txt: Empowering Diverse Voices to Communicate Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the seventh International Conference on Women in Physics (ICWIP), to be held in July 2021.  The purpose of the  conference is three-fold: (i) to provide an opportunity to analyze the current status of and progress in promoting women in physics in each country; (ii) to provide an arena for women in physics to share their scientific accomplishments and create international scientific collaborations; and (iii) to build capacity in each participating country to design and implement changes that improve the participation and advancement of women in physics.  The US delegation will create a virtual workshop focused on effectively communicating science as a result of this conference. This workshop will be given to ICWIP participants, and following the workshop, several ICWIP members will be filmed doing a short, engaging video for a broad audience. After the ICWIP has concluded, the workshop will be disseminated widely and is intended to be offered at conferences and society meetings.

This series of international conferences on women in physics is proving to be an effective mechanism for sharing best practices internationally, empowering new approaches and actions in the U.S., nucleating networking in research, and increasing the numbers, advancement and retention of women in the field. Members of the U.S. Delegation learn about and take advantage of successful initiatives piloted in ~ 50-70 other countries. The U.S. delegation will broaden participation through its diversity: in gender, race/ethnicity, disability status, research specialty (in physics and beyond), career phase and path, employment sector institution type, and geographic location.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Across the globe, women and gender minorities are under-represented in physics. In the US, women earn 20-25% of all physics degrees. The International Union of Pure and Applied Physics has determined that improving the diversity of physics is a key issue for the field, and sponsors the International Conference on Women in Physics every three years. In the US, many projects have worked on supporting women’s advancement in physics. 

 

This project comprised three parts: (a) creating a US delegation to attend the 2020 ICWIP in Australia, (b) producing the Proceedings of the 7th International Conference on Women in Physics to be available open access, and (c) creating a workshop focused on helping women in physics communicate their science. 

 

The 2020 ICWIP in Australia was unfortunately impacted by COVID, and was switched to a virtual conference in July 2021. The initial delegation of 23 traveling and non-traveling was also impacted, and nine delegates were able to attend the virtual conference, hosted by Australia and conducted on Australian time. Since delegates were unable to get the true in-person experience, the 2020 delegates were offered the chance to be delegates for the 2023 conference without having to apply again.  Only a handful of delegates were able to attend the 2023 conference which was virtual, hosted by India, and conducted on Indian time. 

 

The Proceedings of the 7th International Conference on Women in Physics was published in 2023 and is available for open access at https://pubs.aip.org/aip/acp/issue/3040/1.  The Proceedings include reports from each participating country describing the status of women in their countries and the scientific papers from participants.

 

A workshop on communicating science was developed and conducted in the summer of 2024. The workshop covered many topics: Relating your science to what others are saying; elevator pitches; communicating science to the general public; social media; Wikipedia, and branding. Participants worked on Wikipedia pages, wrote and recorded an elevator pitch, and shared stories and successes with each other. Twenty-six short videos were produced, and four new Wikipedia pages were created.

 

Through workshop and conference participation, women physicists were provided with tools to strengthen their connection to the field of physics and to help improve the diversity of the field.
